questions.text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe right-sided temporal headache with conjunctival swelling and anterior bulging of the left eye for 1 hour. The patient has had right-sided purulent nasal discharge and nasal congestion for the past 2 days. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She takes no medications. She appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 40째C (104째F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral ptosis. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Ophthalmic examination shows periorbital edema and chemosis of the left eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient most likely requires treatment with which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Timolol, a topical beta-blocker, is recommended for the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Although this condition would also manifest with a unilateral headache and chemosis, the headache is usually frontal rather than temporal. Acute angle-closure glaucoma primarily affects older individuals and would also cause symptoms such as eye pain and blurred vision. Additionally, acute angle-closure glaucoma does not manifest with periorbital edema, lateral gaze restriction, bilateral ptosis, or fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulants support the recanalization of the dural sinuses and prevent the formation of new thrombi, which decreases the risk of septic emboli. Although some studies have shown a reduction in mortality with the use of heparin, its use remains controversial because it increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications. Because it is difficult to achieve a stable drug level, oral warfarin is generally not recommended in the acute phase of this disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral clindamycin and amoxicillin are an empiric treatment option for preseptal cellulitis (periorbital cellulitis). In preseptal cellulitis, the infection is typically restricted anteriorly by the orbital septum and characterized by unilateral ocular pain with edema and erythema of the eyelid. As most cases of preseptal cellulitis stem from a contiguous skin infection, the orbit is not involved. This patient's ophthalmoplegia, bilateral ptosis, and high fever are not characteristic of preseptal cellulitis and are more concerning for a disseminated infection involving the orbit and paranasal sinuses, for which the combination of oral clindamycin and amoxicillin would not be appropriate.
Image Description:

The left eyelid appears swollen and erythematous.

These clinical features are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis, an inflammation of tissue anterior to the orbital septum.

D) INCORRECT:

Intranasal sumatriptan is indicated for the treatment of cluster headaches and migraines. Either condition can manifest with a severe unilateral headache. However, typical features of a cluster headache include short recurring pain attacks (lasting only minutes) and ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (e.g., lacrimation, nonpurulent nasal discharge, facial sweating), which this patient lacks. As for migraines, patients commonly have nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia, which are also not present here. Neither condition is associated with periorbital edema, chemosis, or fever.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical debridement, along with amphotericin B, is the treatment of choice for mucormycosis, which can manifest with headache, nasal discharge, fever, erythema of the skin overlying the orbit, and cranial nerve palsies, which are seen here. However, this condition is seen almost exclusively in patients who are immunocompromised or diabetic, particularly those with diabetic ketoacidosis, which this patient does not have. Most commonly, such patients develop a rhino-orbital-cerebral infection, which is characterized by the formation of a black eschar on the palate or nasal mucosa due to extensive local tissue necrosis. In septic cavernous sinus thrombosis, endonasal surgery (e.g., sphenoidectomy, ethmoidectomy, mastoidectomy) is only indicated if first-line treatment options are unsuccessful.

F) CORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is the mainstay of treatment for septic cavernous sinus thrombosis. Empiric therapy with vancomycin (for coverage of MRSA) should be combined with a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone or cefepime) and, if the infection originated from the sinus or the teeth, metronidazole (for anaerobic coverage). Affected patients should be treated with high-dose, prolonged antibiotic therapy to reach bacteria sequestered within thrombi. Antifungal therapy (amphotericin B) is indicated in confirmed cases of fungal origin.

G) INCORRECT:

IV dihydroergotamine is an alternative treatment option for the acute management of cluster headaches and migraines in patients who do not respond to the preferred treatment options. Either condition can manifest with a severe unilateral headache. However, typical features of a cluster headache include short recurring pain attacks (lasting only minutes) and ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (e.g., lacrimation, nonpurulent nasal discharge, facial sweating), which this patient lacks. As for migraines, patients commonly have nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia, which are also not present here. Neither condition is associated with periorbital edema, chemosis, or fever.
questions.hint: This patient presents with periorbital edema, chemosis, high fever, and dysfunction of CN III (bilateral ptosis) and CN VI (impaired lateral gaze) 2 days after the onset of sinusitis. These features suggest septic cavernous sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive loss of vision in her left eye and gradual blurring of vision in her right eye over the past 2 months. She also has occasional headaches and noticed a decrease in her sense of smell lately. She has never had these symptoms before. The patient's only medication is fexofenadine for seasonal allergies. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 61 kg (135 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and there is minimal light perception in the left eye. In the swinging flashlight test, both of her eyes dilate as the light moves from the right to left eye. Fundoscopy shows papilledema in the right optic disc and a pale left optic disc. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is the most common inherited optic neuropathy in young adults. Optic neuropathy causes acute visual changes, but it would not cause papilledema or anosmia. Visual field testing demonstrates a central scotoma and telangiectasias around the papilla as well as microangiopathy, none of which are seen in this patient. The lack of family history of optic neuropathy also makes hereditary neuropathy unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudotumor cerebri (i.e., idiopathic intracranial hypertension) should always be considered in women of childbearing age who present with subacute-to-chronic headaches and visual changes. However, pseudotumor cerebri typically affects overweight women, causes bilateral rather than unilateral papilledema, and is rarely associated with anosmia.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) is the most common cause of optic neuropathy in adults > 50 years old and manifests with acute visual loss. Fundoscopic examination would show pale optic disc swelling, sometimes associated with splinter hemorrhages. Unlike in this patient, AION progresses over the course of a few days (not months) and does not cause anosmia.

D) CORRECT:

Frontal lobe tumors, mainly parasellar or subfrontal meningiomas, are the most common cause of Foster-Kennedy syndrome. Anosmia is typically associated with meningiomas arising from the olfactory groove (i.e., from the cribriform plate and frontosphenoidal suture), which account for 22% of all skull base meningiomas. The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is a brain MRI, which is likely to show a round, sharply demarcated space-occupying lesion (resembling a snowball) with significant contrast enhancement. Management is based on the location and grade of the tumor, as well as patient-specific factors (e.g., age, comorbidities, accompanying symptoms). Treatment that reduces elevated intracranial pressure may improve visual function.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a 58-year-old patient with parosmia.

There is a large, well-defined mass with homogeneous contrast enhancement in the olfactory groove (green overlay.

This is an example of an olfactory groove meningioma.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common cause of optic neuritis, especially in women of childbearing age. Optic neuritis can manifest with acute vision change and a relative afferent pupillary defect. While optic neuritis may cause papillitis, which occasionally manifests with papilledema, it does not result in optic atrophy. Also, MS typically manifests with relapsing, remitting neurologic symptoms in anatomically unrelated locations (i.e., symptoms disseminated in time and space), whereas this patient's symptoms are chronic and progressive. Less commonly, MS can cause chronic, progressive symptoms, but it does not cause elevated intracranial pressure, thus it would not explain this patient's headaches.
questions.hint: Ipsilateral atrophy of the optic nerve (as indicated by the pale optic disc and the afferent defect seen in the swinging flashlight test), contralateral papilledema, and anosmia suggest Foster-Kennedy syndrome.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, and double vision. She also has a 2-week history of headache and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Her temperature is 39.4째C (103째F). Examination shows mild swelling around the left eye. Her left eye does not move past midline on far left gaze but moves normally when looking to the right. Corneal reflex is absent. Absence of the corneal reflex is most likely caused by compression of which of the following labeled structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Compression of the abducens nerve can be caused by cavernous sinus thrombosis. Patients present with the inability to abduct the eye, medial strabismus, and diplopia, all of which are seen in this patient. However, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

B) INCORRECT:

Compression of the oculomotor nerve can result from cavernous sinus thrombosis and may manifest with double vision, which is seen in this patient. However, oculomotor nerve palsy also causes ptosis, mydriasis, and a down-and-out pupil. Moreover, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.
Image Description:

Eyes and forehead of a 20-year-old female patient with tubercular meningitis

Image A shows bilateral ptosis, due here to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris. To open her eyes, the patient must contract the frontalis muscle, resulting in the forehead wrinkles seen in image B. Both eyes deviate outwards (exotropia) and downwards (hypotropia) from the primary gaze position. This occurs due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, which are the only unaffected extraocular muscles. Mydriasis indicates involvement of the parasympathetic portion of the oculomotor nerve.

Ptosis, mydriasis, exotropia, and hypotropia are the classic signs of complete oculomotor palsy. Complete oculomotor palsy is more commonly unilateral than bilateral.

C) INCORRECT:

Compression of the trochlear nerve can occur due to cavernous sinus thrombosis and may manifest with double vision, which is seen in this patient. However, trochlear nerve palsy also causes extorsion with an inability to adduct and depress the eye simultaneously. Moreover, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

D) CORRECT:

Compression of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve can be caused by cavernous sinus thrombosis. Affected patients present with an absent corneal reflex and/or impaired sensation in the upper face. Progression of the thrombus results in cavernous sinus syndrome, causing compression of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), trochlear nerve (CN IV), and abducens nerve (CN VI).
Image Description:

The pituitary gland lies within the pituitary fossa and is completely surrounded by the cavernous sinus. The internal carotid artery and the abducens nerve pass through the middle of the cavernous sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic, and maxillary nerve are located towards the lateral wall of the sinus.

E) INCORRECT:

Compression of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve can be due to cavernous sinus thrombosis, which causes loss of sensation of the midface. However, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.
questions.hint: This patient has manifestations of acute bacterial sinusitis (e.g., fever, headache, foul-smelling nasal discharge). Periorbital edema and abducens nerve palsy suggest the development of cavernous sinus thrombosis, a rare but dangerous complication of acute bacterial sinusitis.
